comments.commentBody: Hey, no one is perfect.  Paul may not adhere to all the tenets of kooky Libertarianism but he is the closest thing to it who is in the running (and strongly) to be president of the United States.  Your post gives us even more reason to oppose Paul for president, or for any public office.
Interesting how at the end of her life, Ayn Rand was collecting Social Security and was on Medicare. She was a fraud and a phony.

Sorry David, you are fundamentally wrong.  Ron Paul is a Libertarian...he's a Constitutional Libertarian who believes in a Republic.  That means that he does want a Federal government to do some things (you know, the things enumerated by the Constitution) but the other things can and rightfully should be reserved to the States and the People.

Let us get things straight about Ron Paul and Libertarianism. He is no Libertarian.
The Libertarian Party grew out of the Ayn Rand movement after the publication of Atlas Shrugged. It was an outgrowth of her philosophy of Objectivism, and none of today"s so called Libertarians even come close to following that philosophy.

For one thing she said "No one is an Objectivist, you are students of Objectivism."
To be a Libertarian in the Ayn Rand mold, you would be an Atheist, you would support abortion, you would not support any kind of government financing of anything except the army, the courts, and the police. Everything else would be part of the free market. You can find her principles in "The Ayn Rand Newsletter" and the "Objectivist" which she published along with Nathanial Brandon, and then with Leonard Peikoff.

Ron Paul would be derided by her if she were around today. He and other pseudo Libertarians have taken bits and pieces of Libertarianism, and sold the ones they can make sound good to the public. The last public figure who understood her is Alan Greenspan. The followers of Ron Paul have deluded themselves that they understand the consequences of Paul's proclamations.

If he were a faithful follower of Libertarianism, there would be no social programs, Medicare, SS., interstate highways, bank regulation , securities, public fire departments, public utilities, national parks, or other "Socialist" government activities. Maybe education would be OK, That is it.

Why aren't they making a vaccine right now?
That is the only good that can come from this.
It's insanity to have forced such a mutation as there is not any indication it was occurring naturally or that it would have retained a 50% death rate if it had.

I think Hazare and his team don't know why there is tremendous corruption in India?They are attacking on windmill as a devil just like Don Quixote.Real cause of corruption is Indians afraid too much when they break the law of religion but never afraid or suffered from guilt feeling when the break the law of government. Corruption increased tremendously when British imposed modern law on Indian.This exactly recognized by Lord Cornwallis governor general of India He wrote in 1783 when British introduced their legal system in India He wrote '"No suitor could now hope successfully to plead
his own causes it was essential to employ lawyer for courts.Hampered by the tedious procedure that they had to follow were unable to cope with the number of suit initiated and there
such vast accumulation of arrears.that a suitor was said to lucky if decision was reached in his grandson`s life time" Without gave bribes you did not gate justice in British courts.Naturally corruption increased from that time.
I think real cause of corruption in India is clashes between old values of religious dogma and new secular modern law system When Indians abandoned their old religious dogma and wholeheartedly accept new secular law than only corruption diminished

I found the political aspect interesting as well. I do understand how libertarianism might fit well with the isolation and self-reliance that are hallmarks of life on the spectrum. But I think the opposite is also true. As a social democrat who believes in a strong welfare state, my politics is grounded in empathy. Because politics and policy is discussed in abstraction, I am able to use my advocacy as an outlet for the empathy and kindness that I struggle to express on a personal level.

Farther elaborating on what Uly said, I have AS myself and am on the far left of the political spectrum. Also, aspies actually tend to have GREATER affective empathy(1) than most of the population, which is what the term empathy is usually used to denote in common speech. Every aspie is different.

1. ^ Rogers K, Dziobek I, Hassenstab J, Wolf OT, Convit A. Who cares? Revisiting empathy in Asperger syndrome. J Autism Dev Disord. 2007 Apr;37(4):709-15.

I am a liberal democrat with Aspbergers.  People with Aspbergers have all different political beliefs!  Also although people with Aspergers may seem less empathetic and may not pick up on other peoples feelings they are just as compassionate and sometimes even more so than neurotypicals!

Touching, and hopeful.

However, I find it unsettling - though not surprising - that someone diagnosed with Asperger's should be attracted to Libertarianism, a political philosophy notable for its isolationism, lack of empathy and emphasis on highly rational, absorbed self-interest.

Is it possible that the politicians clustering towards that end of the political spectrum may also be manifesting a variety of neurologically-based "mindblindness" as well?
Occupy Wall Street and DC - OWSDC
If they would simply Respect the Public Trust, they'd be worth their salary. But why would they -- too few voters would ever bother to know or care beyond the superficial ?

The article mentions that Florida was the first to really open up the concealed weapons permit process but completely neglected to tell what happened.

All the media and gun control groups predicted blood flowing in the streets... and then the crime rate went down significantly.

Why do you suppose they left that out?
Yes, it is pitiful that folks spout such stuff as "but in the US they are a neccesity--------------- to kill people just in case they don't measure up to our standards."
Sounds like SOMEone is a little frustrated and jealous ...

Helen Frankenthaler's work offers us something rare in today's art—a glimpse of beauty. She needed no "isms" or categories to box her art into a convenient school or method. She was a pioneer of her day and an inspiration to me personally when I was a young female art student in the late sixties. She was quoted as saying, "For me, being a ‘lady painter' was never an issue. I don't resent being a female painter. I don't exploit it. I paint."  That says it all.
thanks!

Even though she had no interest in feminism, she didn't get her due mainly because she is a woman, her paintings have feminine qualities, therefore they don't have sufficient gravitas.....read suffering or negative emotions that are often associated with great art.  She preceded many of the "great color artists" who were men, yet she isn't often given their same stature.  The sense of expansiveness, color and freedom isn't often seen in art. This art is inspiring and makes you feel good, like many Matisses.  So many artists have suffered and have been poor, it doesn't matter how you grew up if you have vision. RIP Helen.
It feels like you have a constant text for commenting on whatever article that has the word "Israel" in it. No relation to the article subject is needed.

Israel is not a democracy and a failed state,Bibi is not a roll model, in fact far from it,Likes free bees,women power and torturing and dehumanizing Palestinians and controls the American senate and assembly.
Democracies respect international law human rights, UN and do not invade countries and use poison gas, rat poison phosphorous bombs, Condemned WMD. Israel is secretive,does not allow UN observers, has the worlds largest open air prison,3 Bantu concentration camps(West Bank) Imprisons women children and elderly without charges and trial,collective punishment, the list goes on and says they are the GOD'S chosen people and god gave them Palestine and the right to kick out people who lived there for ever. Might is right. Shanti

Ron Paul missed 5 controversial passages over a 20 year period...

Wheres the controversy?

But youre right, peace and fiscal responsibility are WAY over rated.

More wars, more debt!

Is it coincidental that Ron Paul's son has Ayn Rand's last name?

I've read Atlas Shrugged (except for most of the 70 page John Gault rant at the end) and found it simplistic and naive.

Anybody who uses it as a guiding philosophy, or names their son after the author, is not aware of the complexity of our civilization, or is disturbed.
That Ron Paul allowed these racist comments to be published under his name, and that he doesnt' disavow his white supremacist followers, says all you need to know about him and his candidacy.

It is not credible that Paul was not aware that of the content of these newsletters of which there was more than one and from which I understand he made a fine profit from. That he hired writers whose views did not reflect his own, or was unaware of its content is just not believable. Are we to believe that he is this startlingly incompetent and irresponsible as an administrator, and still want to be viewed as presidential?

It seems to me that Paul is trying the old plausible deniability excuse used by politicians when caught in the middle of an embarrassing or potentially illegal situation. This sounds reminiscent of Regan's "I don't recall" refrains when confronted with Iran Contra.

Paul won't disavow racist supporters because in his version of libertarianism, their views are as justified as any other. In Paul's world there would be no civil rights laws. Paul's world would be the a heartless, amoral, nihilistic society that would be an economic and political version of the law of the jungle. with no governmental role in the health and well being of citizens beyond basic police functions.

People get seduced by his anti Iraq and pro marijuana stand, but he feels the same about heroin and cocaine but if you become an addict, you're on your own.

Ron Paul, like his son, Rand is an extremist who shroud racist and fascist views in a pseudo libertarian jargon that seems to stress individual freedom, but really promotes a society based on primitive views of human nature.
agree!  Sublime??????
Maybe he meant subprime.
At John Dory you sit staring at a flashing Halal Meat Sign lightsor watching cabbies eating take out Curry in their filthy cars. It's about as sublime as the Pulaski Skyway!

when you say "a sublime cityscape outside," are you referring to the wholesaler jewelry stores? or the wholesaler wig stores?

a view of Broadway between 29th and 28th is pretty much the least sublime thing I can think of - it's one of the scuzziest and dirtiest parts of manhattan - and that's saying something!

that word that you use, I do not think it means what you think it means.
Did you read the article? "The food — Swedish-African-American in spirit and fact — is not really the point..."

Actually, deGaulle wanted Quebec (not Ontario) to secede from Canada. The Quebequois at the time seemed to suffer a romantic delusion that their province could row itself across the Atlantic and tie up off the mouth of the Seine river. I think they have mostly got over that now.

By contrast, despite all the bilingualism, I have never heard anyone seriously advocate detaching any part of the US and joining it to Mexico or any other Latin American country.
Har!   Boehner gets "Gored"!!

Quoting:  "Tea Partiers also receive their information primarily, or in some cases exclusively, from Fox News and talk radio."  Enough said.  That sentence alone sums up why Tea Partiers must be taken seriously (the power of Fox) and yet shouldn't be taken seriously (the lunacy of Fox).

Your point is well taken, but you're even understating the case. Nobel prize- winning economist Joseph Stiglitz places the true costs of the Iraq war at more like $3T US (http://threetrilliondollarwar.org/)

"...100,000 innocent Iraqi lives"

That,J., is an understatement.

Bush got the approval of congress, Obama did not. This makes Iraq legal and Libya illegal. That said, the Iraq war was nothing more than a vendetta, pure and simple. Bush played on everyone's emotions after 9/11 and it worked. Big George did not pursue the overthrow of Saddam Hussein in the Gulf war because he understood that he was a stabilizing influence in the region. He ran the CIA for a while and knew more than Clinton, Little George or Obama know combined. Iraq was a big mistake. We spent a lot of money and American lives to make the region more unstable. Hell, they have already started fighting amongst themselves...it's all they know.

Please remember the Iraq War when commenting on Mr. Obama's infinitesimal forays into warfare. Iraq cost 1 Trillion dollars, 4,000 American lives, 100,000 innocent Iraqi lives, death, destruction, horrific violence, rampant PTSD and on and on....all unnecessary, all predicated on a false premise....the horrific disaster of my lifetime.

Now, how does Libya or 100 troops into southern Africa stack up?

Michael, the difficulty with what you realize is that "common sense solutions" do not necessarily make sense when applied to complicated systems like our national economy. The size of the national debt is not an immediate problem because we are borrowing money at an infinitesimal interest rate, with no statutory requirement as to when it needs to be paid back. So-called Keynesian economists would say that the government should borrow money in the short term to crank up the economy and reduce unemployment, and then pay it back when the economy is in better shape.

Right now, draconian cuts in federal spending will not cause prosperity, but will only de-stimulate the economy into another recession. And another recession will only make it that much harder - not easier - to pay back any debt. There is also a distinct chance that the national economy could be shocked into a total depression, like 1929-32. At that time, Herbert Hoover believed that avoiding federal debt was the best way to counter the stock market crash. He was very, very wrong.

It's ludicrous that some in the past have liked Mr. Lampert to Warren Buffett, who has a stellar record spanning over 50 years.  One of Buffett's key concepts is from his mentor in "Margin of Safety" and minimizing risk.

Social Security will be paid from the general fund merely because it has become part of the general fund mostly done by the conservative heart throb Reagan.

Conservatives are perfectly happy with their odd socialist entitlements - corporate subsidies and corporate and the wealthy tax loopholes.

“I believe it is the role of government to protect life from conception until natural death, and I will never be confused about that issue.”

Amazing how they can have such a wrong headed and self serving approach to the role of government. To them government has no role in teaching our kids, protecting the poor, the sick or the elderly, protecting our environment, our infrastructure and our economy from the mercilessness of business interests. They absolve the government of those jobs but feel it is reasonable for it to have the government meddle in people's personal and heart-wrenching reproductive choices instead. It makes no sense at all.
